title: Development of a microscopic gas diffusion-reaction model for a H2 producing biocatalyst
abstractText:
Providing the technology for production of renewable energy is one of the grand
challenges of this century. There are alternatives to oil, gas and nuclear such as 
water, wind and solar power. Of those, the latter is a virtually unlimited power source 
and we think that every effort should be undertaken to try to harvest the power 
of the sun. This is not an easy task because light energy needs to 
be converted into a form of energy that can be stored and supplied 
on demand. A convenient storage medium are molecules comprised of atoms
that are held together by energy-rich covalent bonds. Indeed, over millions of years 
nature has stored sun light in form of organic molecules (fossil fuels) via natural 
photosynthesis. A carbon-free alternative storage medium is molecular hydrogen with 
the added advantage that the energy density that can be stored with hydrogen 
is significantly larger than for fossil fuels. Thus, molecular hydrogen is envisaged as one of 
the primary energy carriers of the future. One of the grand challenges for scientists 
is to find or design a cheap catalyst that allows for efficient production of hydrogen from 
sunlight and a source for hydrogen atoms, ideally water. 

Clearly, one of the most sustainable approaches to hydrogen production is 
photocatalytic water oxidation, although this process requires efficient catalysts. 
Their design is by no means trivial and can probably be considered as the holy grail 
of contemporary material science. A viable alternative that we investigate here 
is to exploit biological molecules (hydrogenases) that can be found in microbes 
such as green algae and cyanobacteria capable of photosynthetic water splitting. 
Pilot plants of H2 producing organisms exist, but there are major barriers that must 
be overcome to bring the process to commercial viability. The most important one that 
needs to be addressed is the high sensitivity of the organism's hydrogenase to 
molecular oxygen. Evolved under anaerobic conditions, the biomolecule gets inhibited or 
damaged upon exposure of the oxygen that is around us in the atmosphere. 

There is evidence that hydrogenases may be modified so as to render the molecule 
less sensitive to oxygen. In order to facilitate this optimization process we propose
here to investigate theoretically the primary events of the oxidative damage, that is diffusion 
and binding of oxygen molecules to the active site of hydrogenases, by developing 
novel molecular simulation methods. The simulations will help to understand and 
interpret recent experimental measurements on a molecular level. For example, 
they will allow us to understand which pathways oxygen molecules take before they 
damage the active site and how fast this process occurs. The microscopic information 
gained from simulation will be vital for the suggestion of modifications (mutations) 
of hydrogenase that aim to restrict the access and the binding of molecular oxygen 
while leaving the catalytic power for hydrogen production unchanged. The effects 
of the suggested mutations will be predicted by our simulations and tested in vitro 
by an experimental colleague. 

The long term goal of this project is to obtain a hydrogenase mutant with 
significantly increased aerotolerance, which can be used for hydrogen production 
on a technological scale. This would have a tremendous socio-economic impact 
as the hydrogen industry is likely to take a prominent position on the 
future energy market.
impactText:
At the time of writing this text, work is still being carried out on this project, so it seems too early to make statements about the impact of the developed methodology and results. 

However, it is clear that the project has contributed to the personal development of the PDRA employed, Dr A Kubas.
In his second year of employment, and after publication of his paper in Angewandte, Adam was offered a more senior post-doc position at the Max-Planck Institute for Energy Conversion, Muhlheim, Germany, working in the group directed by Prof F Neese, a highly regarded theoretical Chemist. 

The project has also fostered an interdisciplinary research 
collaboration with Prof L de Gioia (Milan) and Dr C Leger 
(CNRS Marseille), resulting in a two week residential stay in Marseille in March/April 2014. As part of this stay I delivered 
a tutorial talk to undergraduate and graduate students at 
the local universities as well as a research talk to a more senior audience. We have identified future research projects and written a review in a high impact journal (Greco et al Energy and Environmental Science 2014).

Our findings have been presented at a number of invited and contributed talks and at summer schools in 2013-14. As part of our impact plan, we have organised an international conference "Interface between Experimental and Theoretical Approaches to Energy-related Enzyme Catalysis", co-organised by C. Leger, L. De Gioia, R. B. Best, 
http://www.thomasyoungcentre.org/enzyme-catalysis/
The goal of this conference, held at UCL in June 2014, was to showcase synergies between experiment, theory and molecular computations on three very topical themes in energy-related enzyme catalyses: ``Water oxidation in photosystem II&quot;, ``Hydrogenases and synthetic analogues&quot; and ``Multiheme proteins and biological
nanowires&quot;. There were 5 half-day sessions, each dedicated to one of the above themes, with a total of 15 invited talks, including members of the UK SUPERGEN consortium for biological fuel cells, and 12 contributed talks (5 female and 22 male speakers). The quality of both invited and contributed talks was very high, which can be explained by the large number of applications that we have received and the possibility to select from excellent abstracts. Several key issues for future developments were identified in each of the three sub-themes. With 83 participants from 11 European countries and the US attending, this workshop, co-sponsored by the US Office for Naval Research, Royal Society of Chemistry/Faraday Division, Society for Biological Inorganic Chemistry, and EPSRC, was a highly successful event. Chemicals,Energy,Environment Cultural
findingsText:
Objective I: 
&amp;amp;quot;Kinetic model for gas diffusion and binding to proteins. We propose to develop a unified multiscale kinetic model for diffusion and binding of gas molecules in proteins using data from molecular dynamics simulation and quantum mechanical/molecular mechanical calculations. The method will be applied to WT [FeFe]-hydrogenases and the resulting diffusive on-rates for H2 and O2 compared to experimental data and interpreted at a molecular level. We will develop methodology allowing such models to be derived in a systematic way.&amp;amp;quot;

This model has been developed in Wang et al. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 135, 9493 (2013) and applied to CO2 and CO diffusion in CO-dehydrogenase. Applications to O2 and CO diffusion in FeFe hydrogenases are still ongoing and are expected to be 
published end of 2015. 

Objective II. 
&amp;amp;quot;Restricting O2 access. We aim at restricting the access of O2 to the active site of hydrogenases. The nature of the diffusion mechanism and the number of possible entry channels will reveal to which extent this can be efficiently done. On the basis of the characterized diffusion pathways key residues that control the access of O2 will be identified. The nature of these residues will be changed either by point mutations or by chemical modification. The engineered enzyme is then tested for increased H2 versus O2 selectivity in vitro (Leger) and in silico through measurement and computation of the corresponding diffusion rates.&amp;amp;quot; 

A new computational method for the rapid screening of possible mutations that affect ligand binding in proteins has been developed and is currently under review, D. De Sancho, A. Kubas, P. Wang, J. Blumberger, R. B. Best &amp;amp;quot;Identification of Mutation Hot-Spots for Substrate Diffusion in Proteins&amp;amp;quot;. Applications of this method to O2 diffusion in hydrogenase enzymes are still ongoing and are expected to be published end of 2015. 

Objective III. 
&amp;amp;quot;Restricting O2 binding. We aim at restricting the binding of O2 to the metal centers of hydrogenase once it has reached the active site pocket. Residues that form the walls of the active site cavity are mutated so as to increase the H2 versus O2 binding selectivity. The effect of the mutations is investigated by computation of the binding free energies of H2 and O2 at the QM/MM level of theory.&amp;amp;quot;

The mechanism, activation and reaction free energy for O2 binding to two FeFe hydrogenases has been computed and published in Kubas et al Angewandte Chemie 2014, &amp;amp;quot;Aerobic damage of [FeFe] hydrogenases: activation barriers for O2 chemical attachment&amp;amp;quot;. Mutation studies in collaboration with 
C Leger (CNRS Marseille), that aimed at reducing the binding 
affinity of O2 to the active site, did not lead to significantly more robust enzymes (see below). The methodologies developed in Objectives I and II are and will be made available to the scientific community through peer-reviewed publications. The methodologies are very general and can be straightforwardly implemented by others. Alternatively, the corresponding scripts written in perl/python can be obtained from our reserach group upon request. Chemicals,Energy,Environment
